myths.reality: Regular breaks prevent burnout and improve care quality
myths.explanation: Studies show that caregivers who take breaks provide better care and are healthier themselves.

myths.myth: Feeling overwhelmed means you're not cut out for caregiving
myths.reality: Feeling overwhelmed is normal and shows you care deeply
myths.explanation: Even professional caregivers experience stress - it's a sign you're human, not inadequate.

myths.myth: One person should handle all the caregiving responsibilities
myths.reality: Shared caregiving leads to better outcomes for everyone
myths.explanation: Research shows that distributed care reduces stress and provides more comprehensive support.

myths.myth: Family members can't advocate effectively with doctors
myths.reality: Prepared family advocates improve patient outcomes significantly
myths.explanation: Patients with engaged family advocates have fewer medical errors and better care coordination.

myths.myth: Older adults can't learn to use technology for their care
myths.reality: With proper support, most seniors adapt well to helpful technology
myths.explanation: Studies show 70% of seniors successfully use health apps when given appropriate training and support.

myths.myth: You have to correct every confused statement from someone with dementia
myths.reality: Entering their reality often works better than correction
myths.explanation: Therapeutic validation reduces agitation and maintains dignity while providing emotional comfort.

myths.reality: With planning and resources, most families manage caregiving costs effectively
myths.explanation: Various programs, insurance benefits, and cost-effective strategies can make caregiving affordable.

myths.myth: Hiring help means you're giving up or failing
myths.reality: Professional help enhances family care and extends independence
myths.explanation: Combining family and professional care often provides the best outcomes and sustainability.

myths.myth: You can't plan for unpredictable health changes
myths.reality: Flexible planning frameworks help families adapt to any changes
myths.explanation: Good care plans include contingencies and decision-making frameworks for unknown situations.

myths.reality: Men can be equally effective caregivers with different strengths
myths.explanation: Male caregivers often excel at problem-solving, advocacy, and bringing different perspectives to care.

myths.myth: You can only provide good care if you live nearby
myths.reality: Long-distance caregiving can be highly effective with the right strategies
myths.explanation: Technology and local networks allow distant caregivers to coordinate excellent care.

myths.myth: People with dementia can't make any decisions for themselves
myths.reality: Most people with dementia retain decision-making capacity for many choices
myths.explanation: Supporting autonomy in small decisions preserves dignity and can slow cognitive decline.

myths.myth: Medication mistakes are inevitable with complex regimens
myths.reality: Simple systems and tools can virtually eliminate medication errors
myths.explanation: Pill organizers, apps, and shared tracking reduce medication errors by over 75%.

myths.myth: Caregiving means giving up your social life completely
myths.reality: Maintaining relationships and activities is essential for sustainable caregiving
myths.explanation: Caregivers with strong social connections report less stress and provide better care long-term.

myths.myth: Talking about death and dying scares people and makes things worse
myths.reality: Open conversations about preferences reduce anxiety and improve end-of-life care
myths.explanation: Research shows that discussing end-of-life preferences leads to care that better matches patient wishes.

myths.myth: Forcing someone to eat shows you care about their health
myths.reality: Mealtime battles often make eating problems worse
myths.explanation: Creating pleasant meal experiences and offering choices usually improves nutrition better than pressure.

myths.myth: The safest place for someone with dementia is always at home
myths.reality: Safety depends on individual needs, not location
myths.explanation: Some people are safer in specialized care while others thrive at home with proper support.
